facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 160 to 162 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 160 to 162 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated January 20, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Government Appeals Nos. 2011 to 2013 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 20, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Government Appeals Nos. 2011 to 2013 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant was a postman attached to Bulandshahr post office.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, who was a postman attached to the Bulandshahr post office was tried for offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898

facts.text: Appellant tried for offences under s.52 Indian Post Office Act in all three trials, and under ss.467 and 471 IPC in two of them.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, who was a postman attached to the Bulandshahr post office was tried for offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898  VI of 1898  and in two of them, also for offences under ss. 467 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Allegations: appellant stole or secreted five registered letters and fabricated three receipts showing receipt by addressees.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the allegations against the appellant were that he either stole or secreted five registered letters and that he fabricated three receipts showing that the registered letters were received by the addressees.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Bulandshahr acquitted appellant of all offences.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions judge acquitted the appellant of all these offences.

facts.text: State appealed acquittal to Allahabad High Court, restricted to offences under s.52 Post Office Act.

anchor.surface_text: The State then preferred an appeal against his acquittal in these three cases to the High Court of Allahabad but restricted the appeal to the acquittal of the appellant in respect of offences under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898

facts.text: High Court held appellant secreted five registered letters, set aside acquittal, convicted under s.52 Act, sentenced to 1 year RI each case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant had secreted the five registered letters in question and on this finding set aside his acquittal and convicted him in each of the three appeals for offences under s. 52 of the Act and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year in each case.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has come up to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: House search of appellant and father Diwan Singh on May 12, 1956 by I.D. Inspector S.N. Singh and SI Masood Murtaza in connection with case against Messrs Greenwood Publicity.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the prosecution case is that when the house in which the appellant lives along with his father Diwan Singh, a retired Police Head Constable, was searched by the I.D. Inspector, S.N. Singh, along with Masood Murtaza, Sub-Inspector of Police, Bulandshahr on May 12, 1956, in connection with a case against Messrs Greenwood Publicity,

facts.text: During search, large number of letters, postcards, and five registered letters found in almirah; key produced by appellant's father.

anchor.surface_text: they accidentally discovered a large number of letters and postcards and also the five registered letters in question. At the time of the search the appellant who happens to be a trade union official, was not in Bulandshahr but was away on leave at Delhi in connection with a postal conference. These articles were found in an almirah, the key of which was produced by the appellants father.

facts.text: Appellant was away on leave in Delhi for postal conference at time of search.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the search the appellant who happens to be a trade union official, was not in Bulandshahr but was away on leave at Delhi in connection with a postal conference.

facts.text: Articles listed at spot, taken to Kotwali in sealed packet, listed there.

anchor.surface_text: The articles were not listed at the spot but were taken to the Kotwali in a sealed packet and later on listed there.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: articles planted by opposite faction in post office at Kotwali; house and almirah not in exclusive possession.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly, the appellants defence in all these cases is that there are two factions in the Bulandshahr post office and that these articles were planted by the opposite party. According to him, the planting must have occurred in the Kotwali when the Sub-Inspector purported to make a list of the articles seized from the house in which the appellant lives.

facts.text: House rented in father's name, consists of two rooms, both father and appellant live there; almirah in father's possession, key produced by him.

anchor.surface_text: Further, according to him, neither the house nor the almirah from which the articles are said to have been seized was in his exclusive possession. He stated-and that fact is not denied-that the house which consists of two rooms only has been rented in his fathers name, that both of them live in those two rooms and that the almirah was in his fathers possession inasmuch as the key was produced by him.

facts.text: Diwan Singh is retired Police Head Constable.

anchor.surface_text: his father Diwan Singh, a retired Police Head Constable,

facts.text: Appellant is trade union official.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant who happens to be a trade union official,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds search illegality does not vitiate seizure; accepts High Court's finding on seizure.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the alleged illegality of the search is concerned it is sufficient to say that even assuming that the search was illegal the seizure of the articles is not vitiated. ... The High Court has chosen to accept the evidence of the prosecution with regard to the fact of seizure and that being a question to be decided only by the Court of fact, this Court would not re-examine the evidence

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no exclusive possession of letters by appellant established; reverses conviction.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them

facts.text: High Court reasons for possession: appellant had opportunity, some articles addressed to him, father old wouldn't incriminate son, motive.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this question the High Court has observed as follows In the first place, the respondent alone had the opportunity and the means to secure such a large number of postal articles.  2  that at least nine of those postal articles were addressed to the respondent himself  vide Ex. Ka-9, serial number 66 ,  3  that Dewan Singh, who, we are informed is a very old man, would not foist the said incriminating articles on his son

facts.text: At least nine postal articles addressed to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: that at least nine of those postal articles were addressed to the respondent himself  vide Ex. Ka-9, serial number 66 ,

facts.text: Recovery 7-8 months after despatch of letters; no complaints of non-delivery; acknowledgments for three letters in post office.

anchor.surface_text: He further referred to the fact that at least in respect of three of the registered letters acknowledgments purporting to be from the addressee were obtained and were with the post office.

facts.text: Addressees examined, deposed not received letters; believed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The addressees have been examined in this case and they have deposed that the letters in question were not received by them. Their evidence has been believed by the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contravention of ss.103/165 CrPC allows resistance to search and careful scrutiny of seizure evidence but no further vitiation of seizure

holdings.text: High Court acceptance of prosecution evidence on fact of seizure is finding of fact not re-examinable by Supreme Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seizure is pure question of fact for trial court, Supreme Court defers to High Court finding

holdings.text: No entrustment required for post office officer to commit secretion under s.52 Post Office Act

anchor.surface_text: the legislature has deliberately enlarged the scope of s. 52 so as to encompass secretion, destruction or throwing away of postal articles by an officer of the post office even though they may not have been entrusted to him

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: theft/secretion don't require entrustment unlike CBT; contrast with s.55 explicit words; purposive for officers' access during duties

holdings.text: Retention of postal article by post office officer for inordinate period tantamount to secreting

anchor.surface_text: To secrete means, according to the dictionary to hide. In connection with a postal article addressed to some person the fact that it is retained in his possession by an officer of the post office

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning of secrete as hide; context of postal duties infers hiding from prolonged retention

holdings.text: Postal article remains in course of transmission by post despite delay of several months until delivery, return or disposal
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.3(a) definition; common experience of delays; explicit until delivery/return/disposal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledgment raises rebuttable presumption; credible denial by addressees believed by fact court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint house/almirah with father who held key; High Court reasons circular/speculative; rejects opportunity/motive inference without possession proof

holdings.text: Appeal from acquittal treated same as from conviction; no compelling reasons needed to reverse if acquittal unjustified by evidence

anchor.surface_text: this Court has held that an appeal from acquittal need not be treated differently from an appeal from conviction and if the High Court finds that the acquittal is not justified by the evidence on record it can set aside

holdings.text: New grievance of prejudice from s.342 CrPC non-compliance cannot be raised first time in Art.136 appeal

anchor.surface_text: no grievance was made either before the Court of the Additional Sessions judge or before the High Court that there was such a contravention and the appellant was prejudiced and we cannot allow

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prejudice is question of fact; not permitted de novo in constitutional appeal

holdings.text: Ordering consecutive sentences of 1 year RI in three cases under s.52 excessive given maximum 7 years

anchor.surface_text: bearing in mind the fact that the maximum sentence awarded under s. 52 of the Act is seven years it would not be right to say that in ordering the sentences in the three cases to run consecutively the appellant is being very severely punished

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proportionality considering max penalty, but moot as conviction set aside

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we must hold that the prosecution has failed to prove that these letters were in the exclusive possession of the appellant. No presumption can, therefore, be drawn against him that he had secreted them from the mere fact that they were found in the almirah which, at best, may be regarded as being in the joint possession of himself and his father. But, as already stated, even an, inference of joint possession would number be legitimate.
